etymologies: early 17th century: from medieval Latin sensatio(n-), from Latin sensus (see sense)

definitions: a physical feeling or perception resulting from something that happens to or comes into contact with the body

examples.text: a burning sensation in the middle of the chest

shortDefinitions: physical feeling or perception resulting from something that happens to or comes into contact with body

definitions: the capacity to have physical sensations

examples.text: they had lost sensation in one or both forearms

shortDefinitions: capacity to have such feelings or perceptions

examples.text: she had the eerie sensation that she was being watched

definitions: a widespread reaction of interest and excitement

examples.text: his arrest for poisoning caused a sensation

shortDefinitions: widespread reaction of interest and excitement

definitions: a person, object, or event that arouses widespread interest and excitement

examples.text: she was a sensation, the talk of the evening

shortDefinitions: person, object, or event that arouses such interest and excitement
